negotiation_message:
Alice said in round 1: Hi Bob, I see there are 1 book, 4 hats, and 2 balls available. The book has a value of 10 points to me, while the hats and balls are worth 0 points each to me. Would you be willing to let me have the book? I'm happy to let you have all the hats and balls in exchange. Let me know what the items are worth to you and if this proposed split works for you.
Bob replied in round 1: 
Hi Alice,
Thanks for your offer. While I appreciate you letting me have all the hats and balls, the book actually has some value to me as well. The book is worth 2 points to me, each hat is worth 1 point, and each ball is worth 2 points. 

So in total, the 1 book, 4 hats, and 2 balls represent 10 points of value to me. If I let you have the book and I take everything else, the split would be 10 points for you and 8 points for me. That doesn't seem fully fair or envy-free to me.

Would you be open to me taking the book and 2 balls (6 points) and you taking the 4 hats (0 points)? I think that would be more equitable given the items' differing values to each of us. Let me know what you think.
Alice said in round 2: 
I understand your perspective, but I don't think your proposed split of you taking the book and 2 balls (6 points) and me taking the 4 hats (0 points) is fair or envy-free either. That would leave me with no points at all.

The book is by far the most valuable item to me at 10 points. Even though the book is worth 2 points to you, I think the most equitable solution is for me to get the 1 book (10 points) and for you to get the 4 hats and 2 balls (8 points total). 

This way, we both get positive value, and the result is much closer to a 50/50 split. I would be pretty envious if you got the book and balls and I was left with nothing.

So I'd like to propose again that I take the book, and you take all the hats and balls. That's the most fair division I can see given our valuations. Let me know if you can agree to that.
Bob replied in round 2: 
Alice, I hear what you're saying, but I still don't think you getting the book and me getting everything else is a fair 50/50 split given our respective item values.

The book may be worth more to you, but it still has value to me. And the balls are actually worth a decent amount to me as well. I would be somewhat envious seeing you walk away with 10 points while I only get 8 points.

What if we split things this way:
- I get the 1 book (2 points for me) and 1 ball (2 points for me) 
- You get the 4 hats (0 points for you) and 1 ball (0 points for you)

This way, I get 4 points worth of value, and you still get the item most valuable to you, the book, worth 10 points. 

I end up with less overall value (4 points) compared to your proposal where I would get 8 points. But this split feels more equitable and envy-free to me since you're getting the single item you value highly and I'm not left feeling short-changed.

Let me know if this arrangement is agreeable to you. I'm willing to compromise to reach a deal we both feel okay about.
Alice said in round 3: 
Bob, I appreciate you trying to find a compromise. However, I don't think your latest proposal is pareto optimal or envy-free. If I only get the book worth 10 points to me and you get 4 points of value, that's not a balanced split.

I understand the book has some value to you, but it is far and away the most valuable single item to me at 10 points. The balls and hats are worth literally nothing to me.

I think the most equitable and pareto optimal deal is still for me to get the 1 book (10 points) and for you to get everything else - the 4 hats and 2 balls (8 points total).

This way, we are splitting the overall value as close to 50/50 as possible given the items' values to each of us. I would be maximizing my value and you would be getting the most value possible without the book.

I honestly don't see another allocation that is envy-free for both of us and also maximizes each of our points without leaving value on the table. 

So I'd like to firmly propose that as our final deal - I get the book, you get the balls and hats. Let me know if you can agree to those terms and we can conclude the negotiation.
Bob replied in round 3: 
Alice, I understand you really want the book since it's worth a lot to you. But I still don't feel 100% comfortable with you getting 10 points of value while I only get 8 points, even if that's the closest to a 50/50 split we can get given our valuations. It still leaves me feeling slightly envious.

How about this - what if we split the hats 2 and 2 instead of you getting none and me getting all 4? That way, I would get:
- 1 book (2 points) 
- 2 balls (4 points)
- 2 hats (2 points)
For a total of 8 points.

And you would get:
- 2 hats (0 points to you)
So still 10 points total for you with the book.

I realize the extra hats don't add any value for you. But psychologically, I think I would feel better and less envious if we at least split the hats, even if it doesn't change the point totals.

If you can agree to that, I'm ready to accept the deal and conclude our negotiation. You would get your 10 points with the book, and I would get 8 points and feel more satisfied with the equal hat split. Let me know if we can shake on that.
Alice said in round 4: 
Bob, I appreciate you trying to find a solution we can both feel good about. However, I don't see how me getting 2 worthless hats changes anything substantively. The hats add no value for me whether I get 0, 2 or 4 of them. And I would still be getting the 1 book while you get the rest of the items.

I really don't want this negotiation to be hung up on symbolism around the hats. The bottom line is that the 1 book is worth 10 points to me and 0 to me, while everything else is worth 0 to me and 8 points to you in total. 

The only envy-free and pareto optimal deal is for me to get the book and you to get all the hats and balls. That maximizes each of our point totals without leaving any value on the table.

I understand you feeling a little envious since I'm getting 10 points to your 8 with this split. But this allocation gets us as close to equal as possible given the mismatched item values. Any other split leaves one of us with less than our maximum or with items we don't want at all.

So I'd like to insist on my original proposal - I get the 1 book, you get the 4 hats and 2 balls. That's the fairest possible deal in my assessment. Please let me know if you can agree to that, I think we've explored all the options and it's time to wrap up this negotiation. 
Bob replied in round 4: halt negotiation
